The problem with using protected is that we lose the principle of
encapsulation provided by private.

A solution to this problem is embrace incremental development.  a private
method can be built and tested initially with a public modifier.  But at
some point it must be used by an actual intended-to-be-public public method.
Once that public method has been built and tested, we can change the
modifier of the supposed-to-be-private method to private.  That means we
have to remove/comment out the tests that explicitly accessed it: we know
the private method is still working properly because the public method(s)
that use it still run green.

We can't keep all our tests; many of them are just scaffolding to help build
programs.  Once they're of no more use we should discard them.  This is the
sort of refactoring of the test suites required to run all our tests in less
than 10 mins.  

We certainly shouldn't violate the structure of our code just to run some
tests.  Of course using reflection to get at the private methods is a
different kettle of fish and sounds like a neat way around the problem for
those cases when we really need to test the private method directly.  Didn't
someone say they were going to post some code? ;-)

regards, APC

Hi There.

Very often you don't need methods to be "private" to protect them 
from being called from the outside, but "protected" will do the job, 
allowing access only to the class + subclasses of it. 

Here's then some simple suggestions:

A.1) Create a subclass of the class you want to test. Put this class 
in your test package.

A.2) Create a simple delegation method in the subclass with public 
access that calls the protected method. You can also put this method 
directly in the class you want to test, and just remove it before 
releasing. This causes a lot of out commenting though :-)

And something I sometimes do before testing smaller areas...

B.1) change the method access to public for the duration of the test. 
Then change it back to private. This also gives some problems in, 
that you cannot execute automatic tests.


If these suggestions won't do, I see no other way than looking into 
what reflection might do for you.

Regards,
Jakob Jenkov
